8450.explanation: This direction activates on short function words and phrases that serve as transitions or continuations between clauses or ideas (just, it, major, towards, the, part), often appearing at points where the text shifts to a new thought or elaborates on the previous statement.

8526.label: Negation or inability
8526.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that express negation, inability, or impossibility, particularly in phrases like 'can't', 'cannot', 'no choice', and 'can't go/miss/help/stop', indicating a semantic feature for expressing what someone cannot do or what is not possible.

8824.label: Financial/Aid Withdrawal Actions
8824.explanation: This direction activates on tokens describing the removal, cutting, or withholding of financial support, aid, funding, or sanctions directed at entities (countries, organizations, individuals).

8852.label: List item separator punctuation
8852.explanation: This direction activates on commas and 'and' conjunctions that separate items in lists or enumerations within sentences.

8947.label: Applying substance to surface
8947.explanation: This direction activates on verbs and actions describing the application, coating, or treatment of something with a substance or material (covering with tar, equipping with technology, covering with pork, topping with chili, dousing with gasoline, accessorizing, enriching soil, covering walls, covering faces, fertilizing).

9069.label: Sales/promotional urgency markers
9069.explanation: This direction activates on words and phrases that create time-sensitive or limited-availability pressure in marketing and sales contexts, such as 'sale', 'only', 'deal', 'good', 'time', 'OFF', and exclamation marks used to emphasize urgency.

9218.label: Post-related word forms
9218.explanation: This direction activates on various forms and contexts of the word 'post' including 'post' as a noun (blog post, social media post), verb (posted), adjective (post-apocalyptic, post-factual), and compound uses, appearing across diverse text domains.

9270.label: Numerical values and quantities
9270.explanation: This direction activates on specific numbers, prices, measurements, and quantitative values that appear in text, particularly when they represent concrete amounts like currency ($), time zones, screen sizes, data plans, or performance metrics.

9282.label: Distinguishing/Separating Concepts
9282.explanation: This direction activates on words and phrases that explicitly mark the act of making distinctions, separations, or comparisons between two different concepts, categories, or ideas (e.g., 'between', 'separate', 'distinguish', 'from', 'difference').

9361.label: Legislative bill references
9361.explanation: This direction activates on mentions of proposed legislation or bills being discussed, debated, or voted on in legislative contexts.

9439.label: Genre/Category descriptors
9439.explanation: This direction activates on adjectives and nouns that describe media genres, styles, or categorical classifications (autobiography, biographical, socialist, comedy, thriller, paranoid, handheld, melancholy, documentary).

9487.label: Sample/specimen reference
9487.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'sample' (or 'Sample') when used to refer to a representative portion, specimen, or example taken from a larger population or collection for analysis, testing, or demonstration purposes.

9579.label: Name fragments or surname parts
9579.explanation: This direction activates on partial names, surnames, or name components that appear to be cut off or fragmented within text, such as 'Ros' (Roslovic), 'Stur' (Sturtevant), 'Hey' (Heymann), 'Sch' (Schmuck/Schake), 'Cab' (Cabigting), 'Wool' (Woolley), 'asc' (Gascoyne), 'Sorbe', and 'Ped' (Pedriana).

9661.label: Destination/Location tokens
9661.explanation: This direction activates on tokens representing destinations or target locations in travel/movement contexts (Ahmedabad, Beijing, Gaza, Brisbane, Kolkata, home, village, work).

9969.label: Year digit in dates
9969.explanation: This direction activates on the '0' digit appearing in the middle of four-digit years (2007, 2008, 2015, 2009, 2006, 2008, 2012, 2000, 2009), consistently firing when this specific numeral appears in temporal references.

10064.label: Discourse transition phrases
10064.explanation: This direction activates on first-person pronouns ('you', 'I') that introduce a new clause or shift in narrative perspective, typically used to transition between different topics or provide clarification.

10078.label: Question mark punctuation
10078.explanation: This direction activates strongly on tokens immediately following question marks, capturing the punctuation mark itself or the transition point after interrogative sentences.

10162.label: Narrative description prepositions
10162.explanation: This direction activates on prepositions and verbs that introduce or describe the subject matter of creative works (of, about, depicting, explore), functioning as bridges between a work's title/creator and its thematic content.

10172.label: Product/Company names
10172.explanation: This direction activates on proper nouns referring to specific products, companies, technologies, or brand names (ZEISS, Cisco, CeramicSpeed, Novanta, FOX, GE Power Conversion, etc.) that appear in technical or commercial contexts.

10224.label: First-person casual acknowledgment
10224.explanation: This direction activates on instances where speakers use first-person verbs (get, make, bring, acquire) to acknowledge, understand, or relate to a situation in a conversational or empathetic way.

10253.label: Postal codes and addresses
10253.explanation: This direction activates strongly on postal/zip codes and address-related formatting, including location identifiers like '90025', '02138', '02130', and geographic coordinate-like patterns.

10385.label: Medical/Healthcare domain
10385.explanation: This direction activates strongly on the word 'medical' and related healthcare contexts, appearing consistently as a domain marker in text about hospitals, doctors, medical research, and health-related topics.

10765.label: Media attention/newsworthy event
10765.explanation: This direction activates on phrases indicating that someone or something has attracted public attention or become a news story, such as 'made headlines', 'made news', 'flipped the script', 'paid off', or 'making headlines'.

10780.label: Mountain terrain/geography
10780.explanation: This direction activates strongly on the word 'mountain' and its variants across diverse contexts including geography, sports, wildlife, and gaming, indicating it represents a topographic or geographical feature concept.

11007.label: Musical ensemble/instrument types
11007.explanation: This direction activates on words referring to specific types of musical ensembles, instruments, or musical groupings (brass, winds, viola, orchestral, orchestra, piano, symphony, chamber).

11017.label: Ease/Simplicity modifiers
11017.explanation: This direction activates on adverbs and auxiliary verbs that express ease, simplicity, or capability (could, to, easily, allow, for, be) typically appearing in contexts describing how straightforward or uncomplicated something is to do or understand.

11070.label: Temporal reference markers
11070.explanation: This direction activates on words that establish when an event occurred relative to the present moment, such as 'last', 'this' (week/Friday/morning), and 'late' (last month), which serve as temporal anchors in news and narrative contexts.

11302.label: Professional title/role mention
11302.explanation: This direction activates when text mentions professional titles or official positions such as 'attorney', 'Attorney General', or similar role designations, often appearing before or after a person's name.

11431.label: Direct speech attribution
11431.explanation: This direction activates at points where direct quotations or statements from named individuals are introduced or concluded, typically marked by verbs like 'says', 'said', or punctuation indicating speech boundaries.

11479.label: Communication/Expression verbs
11479.explanation: This direction activates on verbs related to conveying, expressing, or representing information, ideas, or meaning (express, convey, represent, expressing).

11753.label: Indefinite pronoun/quantifier
11753.explanation: This direction activates on indefinite pronouns and quantifiers like 'you', 'can', 'that', 'who', 'drug', and 'anything' that appear in contexts expressing generality, possibility, or non-specific reference.

11895.label: Adjective or descriptor token
11895.explanation: This direction activates on words that function as modifiers or descriptors (functioning, warrior, funded, donated, her, Transformers, human, Dior, enough) appearing in positions where they qualify or characterize nouns or concepts.

12003.label: Prepositional phrase 'with'
12003.explanation: This direction consistently activates on the word 'with' when it appears as a preposition introducing a noun phrase or clause that provides additional information or context about the preceding statement.

12378.label: Release/Publication Action
12378.explanation: This direction activates on instances of the word 'release' or 'released' used as a verb indicating the act of making something public, available, or known (statements, footage, images, music, reports, apologies, etc.).

12574.label: Text content or message
12574.explanation: This direction activates when tokens introduce or precede the actual textual content of written messages, signs, notes, or statements (such as 'with', 'read', 'the', 'showing', 'reading', 'saying'), marking the boundary between narrative framing and the quoted or described text itself.

12615.label: Beginner/novice skill level
12615.explanation: This direction activates on words and phrases indicating someone is new to or inexperienced with a particular skill, activity, or field (beginner, novice, newcomer).

12627.label: Temporal transition phrases
12627.explanation: This direction activates on words that introduce time shifts or sequence progression in narratives, such as 'following', 'next', 'couple', 'few', 'other', and 'every other', which typically mark transitions between events or time periods.

12653.label: Hardware component specifications
12653.explanation: This direction activates on technical specifications of computing and automotive hardware components, particularly processor types, architectures, and performance metrics mentioned in product descriptions and reviews.

12673.label: Period/sentence ending punctuation
12673.explanation: This direction activates strongly on periods (.) that mark the end of sentences or clauses, appearing consistently across diverse text contexts as natural sentence boundaries.

12746.label: Passive voice / past participle
12746.explanation: This direction activates on past participle verb forms (determined, determining, corporate, desk-top) that often appear in passive voice constructions or as adjectives modifying nouns.

12769.label: Discourse continuation markers
12769.explanation: This direction activates on words that serve as bridges or connectors between clauses or ideas, often appearing at points where the narrative shifts or elaborates on a previous statement.

12827.label: Doctor title abbreviation
12827.explanation: This direction activates on the token '[Dr]', '[Dr.]', '[Doctor]', or '[doctors]' - specifically the abbreviated or full form of the medical professional title that appears in text.

12889.label: Action verb tokens
12889.explanation: This direction activates on common action verbs (your, on, grab, hopped, belongings) that typically appear in narrative or instructional contexts describing physical or deliberate actions.

12953.label: Discourse connectives and transitions
12953.explanation: This direction activates on conjunctions and transitional words (and, but, however, so, ',') that connect clauses or shift between ideas in discourse.

13130.label: Spectacle and Entertainment
13130.explanation: This direction activates on words describing visually impressive, entertaining, or attention-grabbing aspects of sports, events, and performances that captivate audiences.

13230.label: Ice-related terms
13230.explanation: This direction activates strongly on the word 'ice' appearing in various contexts including ice cream, ice hockey, ice rinks, glaciers, and ice fractures.

13235.label: Attribution phrase 'said'
13235.explanation: This direction consistently activates on the word 'said' when used as an attribution verb in news reporting (e.g., 'police said', 'officials said', 'authorities said'), marking the source of reported information.

13374.label: Public sphere/domain
13374.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'public' when it appears in contexts referring to public institutions, services, spaces, or discourse (public venues, public expression, public anger, public officials, public debt, public art, public places, public services).

13561.label: Comma before continuation
13561.explanation: This direction activates at commas that separate clauses or continue narrative flow, particularly where the comma precedes a shift in topic, perspective, or continuation of a story.

13615.label: Passive voice or dative constructions
13615.explanation: This direction activates on prepositions and pronouns that appear in passive voice structures, dative constructions, or indirect object patterns (e.g., 'to you', 'to him', 'to everyone', 'happened to', 'in adulthood'), where the bracketed token marks the recipient or location of an action rather than the agent.

13620.label: Supply noun usage
13620.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'supply' when used as a noun referring to the availability or quantity of goods, resources, or materials in various contexts (crude oil, batteries, housing, handguns, food, fuel, etc.).

13935.label: Reaching out/contacting
13935.explanation: This direction activates on instances where someone or some entity makes contact, reaches out to, or initiates communication with another person or organization.

13992.label: Salary amount tokens
13992.explanation: This direction activates on numerical values and the word 'salary' when discussing compensation amounts, particularly at positions where specific dollar figures or salary ranges are mentioned.

14022.label: Race-related discourse
14022.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'race' in contexts discussing racial topics, including race relations, racial discrimination, race-baiting, Native American genocide, and racial characteristics.

14024.label: Conditional/Purpose Clauses
14024.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that introduce conditional or purposive relationships ('if', 'order', 'to', 'for') that connect actions or states to their conditions or intended outcomes.

14069.label: Meeting/Encounter verb
14069.explanation: This direction activates on the word 'meet' and its variants (meets, meeting, met) across diverse contexts ranging from casual encounters to formal meetings.

14213.label: Process completion or action finality
14213.explanation: This direction activates on words describing the end state or completion of processes, actions, or operations (allocates, take, completed, can, process, building, that, request, I/O, complete).

14236.label: Word segmentation/morpheme boundaries
14236.explanation: This direction activates at points where words are split mid-morpheme or where morphological boundaries occur within tokens, such as 'evis[cer]ation', 'circum[cis]ers', 'dual-w[ield]ing', and 'UNTR[IM]MED'.

14548.label: Acronym or abbreviation token
14548.explanation: This direction activates on two-letter or three-letter acronyms and abbreviations that appear in brackets, such as [WTF], [GT], [Kotaku], [KT], [KTLA], representing common abbreviations for organizations, websites, and media outlets.

14763.label: Word 'situation' or variants
14763.explanation: This direction fires strongly on the word 'situation' and its variants (situations, Situation, Situ) appearing across diverse contexts.

15181.label: Quoted speech attribution
15181.explanation: This direction activates on verbs and words that introduce or attribute direct or indirect speech, such as 'told', 'said', 'asked', 'declined', 'refused', and names of speakers in quotation contexts.

15187.label: Basketball league abbreviations
15187.explanation: This direction activates on mentions of basketball-related acronyms and league names (NBA, FIBA, basketball) that appear in sports text.

15349.label: Copula 'is' verb form
15349.explanation: This direction activates on instances of the verb 'is' (or related copula forms like 'was', 'are') appearing in bracketed positions, particularly in contexts where the copula links a subject to a predicate nominative or adjective.

15568.label: Geographic location names
15568.explanation: This direction activates strongly on place names (countries, cities, and states) that appear in brackets within news articles and text passages.

15656.label: Event location preposition
15656.explanation: This direction activates on prepositions (at, during, in, the) that introduce the location or venue where an event takes place.

15799.label: Descriptive adjectives and qualifiers
15799.explanation: This direction activates on words that describe or qualify nouns and concepts, such as 'question', 'stating', 'testable', 'vague', 'broad', 'original', and 'be', which function as descriptive or qualifying elements in sentences.

15946.label: Historical/Ancient Time References
15946.explanation: This direction activates on words and phrases that reference ancient civilizations, prehistoric periods, or distant historical time periods (ancient Rome, ancient China, prehistoric, oldest, 7000 BC, etc.).

16007.label: Casual/Colloquial Interjections
16007.explanation: This direction activates on informal discourse markers and casual intensifiers (because, fucking, sucks, awesome, shitty, that's) that appear in conversational or opinionated writing to add emphasis or transition between ideas.

16178.label: Direct speech attribution
16178.explanation: This direction activates at the opening quotation mark of direct dialogue, particularly when a quote begins a new sentence or paragraph following narrative context.

16280.label: Parenthetical/bracketed clarifications
16280.explanation: This direction activates on tokens that appear within parentheses, brackets, or other clarifying punctuation marks that provide supplementary information or asides to the main text.
